importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report marks the latest update on the flooding situation in Mexico, providing current context for the ongoing disaster response and recovery efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over a period of time last week, establishing the timeline of the disaster and the urgency of the response actions.
The heaviest rainfall was reported on Wednesday, indicating the peak of the disaster and the most severe weather conditions.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died due to heavy rains and flooding in five Mexican states.
The state of Veracruz has confirmed 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and one in Queretaro.
Another 65 people are still missing, with 43 reported missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops, including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
Early estimates show that about 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers having 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply across the five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death toll and missing persons during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no clear meteorological warnings that could have predicted the magnitude of the rainfall, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning system.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding and landslides across five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The most affected states were Veracruz, with 29 deaths, Hidalgo with 21 deaths, and Puebla with 13 deaths. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (286mm). Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to provide food, clean water, and emergency aid, while nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity supply. The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) and President Claudia Sheinbaum addressed the crisis, with Sheinbaum noting that no prior meteorological warnings indicated the rain’s magnitude, raising concerns about the country’s alert system.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
